text:
"The Beautyful Ones" May Have Arrived is part of a series of works whose titles echo quotes from the 1968 debut novel of the Ghanian writer Ayi Kwei Armah (born 1939). Armah’s book tells the story of an unnamed railway clerk living in post-colonial Ghana as he struggles to resist corruption in the weeks leading up to the coup against Kwame Nkrumah’s government in 1966. 

The editioned screenprint is Njideka Akunyili Crosby’s first major collaborative print project and features the artist herself wearing an elaborately patterned Ankara style dress, sitting on the floor of a domestic interior faced away from the viewer, surrounded by various images sourced from the internet and Crosby’s personal collection of photographs. The scene suggests a rich inner life stemming from her cross-cultural experiences of growing up in Nigeria and living as an adult in the United States. Reflecting on her past, Crosby contemplates hopes and dreams for the future.
title: "The Beautyful Ones" May Have Arrived
